Max Blumenthal responds to the Washington Post's libelous attack on The Grayzone. 
(2 of 2) (Part 1)

Our phone call – which she solicited – was on the record. Why did she neglect to quote any of it in her article about us?

And why did Washington Post editors assign an article on an emotionally fraught topic like October 7 to an ideologically committed, anti-Palestinian Zionist like Elizabeth Dwoskin, who has denigrated Palestinians as nationless "desert Bedouins"?

Can you describe the nature of your relationship with the Israeli government? Does the Washington Post route stories on the Israeli assault on Gaza through its Tel Aviv bureau, as CNN does – thus placing reporters at the mercy of the Israeli military censor? Would the Washington Post honor a request by a Russian government official to retroactively censor remarks which were “not authorized for publication"?

Finally, why has the Washington Post failed to report on the scandal of friendly fire deaths on October 7, while Israeli mainstream media is publishing shocking investigations on the topic? For example, the most popular outlet in Israel, Yediot Ahronoth, has revealed the following:

-Israel ordered all combat units on October 7 to stop Palestinian fighters from returning to Gaza with captives "at all costs".
-This was an order "to use the 'Hannibal Procedure,' although without clearly mentioning this explicit name". -70 vehicles came under attack "by a combat helicopter, an anti-tank missile or a tank, and at least in some cases everyone in the vehicle was killed." -"It is not clear at this time how many of the abductees were killed due to the activation of this command"

Why, when Israeli family members of hostages are openly accusing Israel's military of killing their loved ones under the notorious Hannibal Directive, is the Washington Post smearing the independent journalists who helped break this titanic political scandal?

As I attempted to explain to Dwoskin during our public call, the aforementioned errors and omissions help explain why so many Americans have turned away in disgust from corporate outlets like the Washington Post, and are instead tuning into independent journalistic ventures like The Grayzone.

Max Blumenthal responds to the Washington Post's libelous attack on The Grayzone. 
(1 of 2) (Part 2)

[In response to Elizabeth Dwoskin's tweet,] I sent the following note to WaPo exec editor @SallyBuzbee and her colleagues demanding corrections of Dwoskin's errors and an explanation of journalistic malpractice in her malicious smear of The Grayzone. Unsurprisingly, no response.

I am the founder and editor-in-chief of TheGrayzone.com. Our publication came under attack in the Washington Post by your "Silicon Valley correspondent" Elizabeth Dwoskin, who slanderously accused us of inspiring "a growing movement with ties to Holocaust denial [which] is effacing history in real-time" related to the events of October 7.

Because Dwoskin's article contained so many demonstrably false statements and journalistically irresponsible omissions, we have published the following response on our site.

We are writing to ask for your cooperation in helping us address the following questions, and to issue corrections:

Dwoskin's article falsely claims, "articles on Electronic Intifada and Grayzone exaggerated these claims to suggest that most Israeli deaths were caused by friendly fire, not Hamas."

In fact, we have not claimed that most Israeli deaths on October 7 were caused by friendly fire, either on our website, on social media, or in public discussions of the event. If this statement by Dwoskin can not be sourced to anything we wrote or said, it must be publicly retracted.

Dwoskin falsely claims, "the [Israeli] army has said it will investigate" friendly fire deaths on October 7. To prove her point, she links to the following Associated Press article, which states, "The military has said it will conduct a thorough investigation of everything that went wrong on Oct. 7 and the days that followed once its war on Hamas is over."

However, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insists the war must continue until the end of 2024. Further, the AP article goes on to state, "But that’s not soon enough for some family members of 13 people killed [by Israeli friendly fire] during a violent standoff between Hamas and Israeli security forces at Kibbutz Be’eri, along the Gaza border."

In other words, the Israeli military has not announced any concrete plans to investigate friendly fire deaths. On the contrary, the families of Israeli victims of IDF friendly fire in Kibbutz Beeri on October 7 have been stonewalled, and they are furious about it.

Dwoskin's claim is therefore false – debunked by the very article she linked to – and must be corrected.

Dwoskin's article relies heavily on "research" by the National Contagion Research Institute (NCRI) and its founder, Joel Finkelstein. She failed to mention that the NCRI is formally partnered with the Anti-Defamation League (see attachment), a pro-Israel lobbying organization that previously employed Finkelstein as a research fellow. According to Joel Finkelstein's LinkedIn profile, he was simultaneously a research fellow with the ADL and running NCRI between December 2018 and October 2020. See here.

Why was the shadowy NCRI's organizational affiliation with a notoriously censorious pro-Israel pressure group not acknowledged to readers of the Washington Post? Are your readers not entitled to transparency about the ulterior sectarian agendas of the supposed experts cited by your reporters?

In a public phone conversation which Dwoskin solicited with me, I and my colleague, Aaron Mate, challenged Dwoskin's claims about our "minimizing" of atrocities on October 7. We also questioned her about her ideological dedication to Zionism and the state of Israel – an obvious conflict of interest which contravenes the Washington Post's proclaimed dedication to objectivity.

When we asked her about an editorial she wrote for the Columbia Spectator in which she justified Zionist colonization of Palestine on the grounds that Palestinians were "desert Bedouins without a sense of national identity as we know it today," Dwoskin hung up on us.
